title: Identification guide of mesozooplanktonic organisms in the Ligurian Sea
text:
This book aims to provide a simple guide for the identification of mesozooplanktonic organisms in the Ligurian Sea.
This guide follows two previous guides in French:

Guide d’identification du mesozooplancton en Mer Ligurienne : version 1
Guide d’identification du mesozooplancton en Mer Ligurienne : version 2

This book is a Quarto book. To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
The classification is broken down into 6 levels:

N1 : quick and convenient separation into 5 groups. The groups are as follows: Plankton_crustacea, Plankton_dark, Plankton_gelatinous, Plankton_small, alter .
N2 : Separation mainly on the basis of phyla into 13 groups
N3 : Separation mainly on the basis of Class into 31 groupes
N4 : Separation on the basis of Orders (if possible) into 54 groups
N5 : Separation on the basis of Sub-orders and Genres into 71 groups
N6 : Separation on the basis of species into 22 groups

The tree structure of the different groups can be viewed below. A mindmap view is also available here.

fs::dir_tree("training_set/", type = "directory")

title: 3  Plankton_dark
text:
source("R/init.R")
vigns <- fs::dir_ls(
  here::here(training_dir, "Plankton_dark"), 
  type = "file", glob = "*.png", recurse = TRUE)

title: 3  Plankton_dark
text:
3.1 Mollusca

3.1.1 Bivalvia

3.1.1.1 Bivalvia_larva

3.1.1.1.1 Bivalvia_veliger






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


The shell of the bivalve has two part a clearer convex valve and a darker triangular protuberence on the images called the umbo (Figure 3.1) . The umbo is above the hinge.


















Figure 3.1: Bivalvia images from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)






3.1.2 Gastropoda

3.1.2.1 Pteropoda

3.1.2.1.1 Limacinidae






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


The limacinidae have easily identifiable spiral shells ( Figure 3.2 ).


















Figure 3.2: Limacinidae images from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)




3.1.2.1.2 Cavoliniidae
The Cavoliniidae is shaped like a cone ( a french fry cones ;) ). The cone becomes wider and wider from bottom to top ( Figure 3.3 )

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Cavoliniidae")




Figure 3.3: Vignettes of the Cavoliniidae




This group is similar to the Cavoliniidae group in ZooScanNet ( Figure 3.4 )


















Figure 3.4: Cavoliniidae images from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)




3.1.2.1.3 Creseideae






Note



The distinctions are interesting but these classes include few individuals.



3.1.2.1.3.1 Creseis_acicula
Creseis acicula is the name recognised by IZBN. Creseis clava is not recognised by IZBN (Horton et al. 2022). The name of this group The name of this group is changed from Dugauquier (2019).
C. acicula has a long and very thin shell.
The ZooScanNet includes the Creseis group and does not go further in the classification (Elineau et al. 2018). However, it is possible to refine this classification and recognise Creseis acicula in the ZooScanNet images ( Figure 3.5 ).


















Figure 3.5: Creseis acicula images from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)




3.1.2.1.3.2 Creseis_conica
The C. conica has a slightly curved conical shell but less marked than for Creseis virgula, see Section 3.1.2.1.3.3 (Figure 3.6). The shell is also shorter and wider than that of Creseis acicula, see Section 3.1.2.1.3.1 .

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Creseis_conica", ny = 2)




Figure 3.6: Vignettes of the Creseis conica




The ZooScanNet includes the Creseis group and does not go further in the classification (Elineau et al. 2018). However, it is possible to refine this classification and recognise Creseis acicula in the ZooScanNet images ( Figure 3.7 ).


















Figure 3.7: Creseis conica images from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)




3.1.2.1.3.3 Creseis_virgula
The shell of Creseis virgula is conical with a pronounced curvature at the apex ( Figure 3.8 ).

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Creseis_virgula")




Figure 3.8: Vignettes of the Creseis virgula

title: 3  Plankton_dark
text:
3.2 Annelida
The main characteristic of this phylum is the vermiform and metamerised body in several segments along a longitudinal axis.

3.2.1 Polychaeta
Parapods are the key to recognising polycheata.

3.2.1.1 Phyllodocida

3.2.1.1.1 Tomopteridae






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


The zooscannet includes the Tomopteridae group. These organisms have biramidal parapodia and a very flat body ( Figure 3.9 ).


















Figure 3.9: Tomopteridae images from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)






3.2.2 Annelida_adult

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Annelida_adult")




Figure 3.10: Vignettes of the Annelida




The zooscannet includes a similar group named annelida (Figure 3.11).


















Figure 3.11: Annelida images from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)




3.2.3 Annelida_larva

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Annelida_larva")




Figure 3.12: Vignettes of the larva of Annelida




The zooscannet includes a similar group named larvae__annelida (Figure 3.13).


















Figure 3.13: Images of the larva of Annelida from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)

title: 3  Plankton_dark
text:
3.3 Vertebrata

3.3.1 Actinopterygii

3.3.1.1 Actinopterygii_larva

3.3.1.1.1 Actinopterygii_alevin

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Actinopterygii_alevin", ny = 2, nx = 2)




Figure 3.14: Vignettes of the Actinopterygii alevin






3.3.1.1.2 Actinopterygii_fry_type1

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Actinopterygii_fry_type1", ny = 2, nx = 3)




Figure 3.15: Vignettes of the Actinopterydii type 1






3.3.1.1.3 Actinopterygii_fry_type2

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Actinopterygii_fry_type2", ny = 2, nx = 3)




Figure 3.16: Vignettes of the Actinopterydii type 2









Dugauquier, Rémy. 2019. “Classification Supervisée Du Mésozooplancton de Calvi : Mise Au Point de Méthodes d’étude Des Classes Rares d’un Set d’apprentissage Et Mise En Contexte Environnemental.” PhD thesis, Mons, Belgique.


Elineau, Amanda, Corinne Desnos, Laetitia Jalabert, Marion Olivier, Jean-Baptiste Romagnan, Manoela Costa Brandao, Fabien Lombard, et al. 2018. “ZooScanNet: Plankton Images Captured with the ZooScan.” https://doi.org/10.17882/55741.


Horton, T., A. Kroh, S. Ahyong, N. Bailly, R. Bieler, C. B. Boyko, S. N. Brandão, et al. 2022. “World Register of Marine Species (WoRMS),” May. https://www.marinespecies.org.

title: 4  Plankton_gelatinous
text:
source("R/init.R")
vigns <- fs::dir_ls(
  here::here(training_dir, "Plankton_gelatinous"), 
  type = "file", glob = "*.png", recurse = TRUE)

title: 4  Plankton_gelatinous
text:
4.1 Tunicata
Tunicates are a subphylum of the Chordates. Their name comes from the tunic produced by the epidermis covering them. The larval stage of these organisms has a notochord (not present in the adult stage) (Ruppert, Fox, and Barnes 2004).

4.1.1 Thaliacea

4.1.1.1 Salpida

4.1.1.1.1 salpidae
These organisms are transparent, which is indicated by the very light yellow on the vignettes. The band of muscle present in the Doliolida is not present. There is, however, the presence of muscle. The barrel shape of the Doliolida is not present. ( Section 4.1.1.3 ).



Vignette (A) and Image (B) of Salpida (Caicci et al. 2013).


Figure 4.1 shows several vignettes of Salpidae.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Salpidae")




Figure 4.1: Vignettes of the Salpidae




This group is similar to the salpida group in ZooScanNet (Figure 4.2).


















Figure 4.2: Images of the Salpida from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).





4.1.1.2 Pyrosomatida

4.1.1.2.1 Pyrosomatida






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


Pyrosomatida forms large tubular colonies several metres long. They are made up of thousands of blastozoids whose tunics are grouped together and the buccal siphon opens in the centre of the tube (Caicci et al. 2013).



Figure 4.3: Image of the Pyrosomatida (Caicci et al. 2013).


In the ZooScanNet, they are very often found in the form of colonies (Figure 4.4). The pharynx is discernible in each image


















Figure 4.4: Images of Pyrosomatida from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).





4.1.1.3 Doliolida
These organisms have the appearance of a symmetrical barrel with a ring of several circles (Figure 4.5). Circles are muscles surrounding the body of the organism



Figure 4.5: Vignette (A) and image (B) of Doliolida (Caicci et al. 2013).


Figure 4.6 shows several vignettes of Sagittoidea. These organisms are transparent as indicated by the light yellow parts on the vignettes. The muscle bands around the organisms appear darker.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Doliolida", nx = 3,ny = 2)




Figure 4.6: Vignettes of Doliolida




This group is similar to doliolida in ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.7 ).


















Figure 4.7: Images of Doliolida from ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)





4.1.2 Appendicularia
Appendidicularia keep their tails in the adult state. This neotenic character makes them easily identifiable. These organisms are divided into two parts: the trunk and the tail ( Figure 4.8 ).



Figure 4.8: Vignette of Appendicularia: A trunk B tail (Quivy, Thomas 2018).



4.1.2.1 Copelata

4.1.2.1.1 Oikopleuridae
The trunk is globular and all organs are tightened. The colour of the trunk is very dark. The subchordal cells arround the notochord give a dark of the tail (Figure 4.9).



Figure 4.9: Vignette (A) and image (B) of Oikopleuridae (Hecq, Collignon, and Goffart 2014)


Figure 4.10 shows severals vignettes of Oikopleuridae.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Oikopleuridae")




Figure 4.10: Vignettes de Oikopleuridae






4.1.2.1.2 Fritillariidae
The trunk of these organisims is elongated. The trunk is less dense and compact than that of the OIkoploridae ( see Section 4.1.2.1.1 ). The colour of the tail of these organisms is rather light on the vignettes (Figure 4.11).



Figure 4.11: Vignette (A) and image of Fritillariidae (Hecq, Collignon, and Goffart 2014)


Figure 4.12 shows several vignettes of Fritillariidae.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Fritillariidae")




Figure 4.12: Vignettes of Fritillariidae







4.1.2.2 Appendicularia_tail
The organism is often damaged during the haul. As a result, appendicular tails are found in the samples (Figure 4.13). There is a light band arround two dark bands (Gorsky and Castellani 2017).



Figure 4.13: Vignette of the Appendicularia tail : muscle, B notochord (Quivy, Thomas 2018).


Figure 4.14 shows several vignettes of the Appendicularia tail.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Appendicularia_tail")




Figure 4.14: Vignettes of Appendicularia tails.




This group is similar to the tail__appendicularia group in ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.15 ).


















Figure 4.15: Images of Appendicularia tails fromZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).

title: 4  Plankton_gelatinous
text:
4.2 Chaetognatha
Les Chaetognatha sont des prédateurs pélagiques bien étudiée. Ils sont les principaux prédateurs des copépodes. La Figure 4.16 montre les 3 parties caractéristiques de ces organismes : tête, tronc, queue (Pierrots-Bults 2017) .



Figure 4.16: Vignette d’un Chaetognatha et ses caractéristiques : tête (A), tronc (B), queue (C) et les crochets (D) (Quivy, Thomas 2018).


Les nageoires sont utilisées afin de déterminer les espèces des chaetognathes (Pierrot-Bults 2020). L’analyse d’image qui permet d’obtenir les vignettes ne permet pas de conserver une précision suffisante des nageoires (Dugauquier 2019).

4.2.1 Sagittoidea
On discrimine les Phragmophora, des Aphragmophora de par la présence d’un musculature transversale et des structure glandulaires sur la surface du corps abondante. Dugauquier (2019) a approfondi la classification en Krohnittidae, Sagittidae et Eukrohniidae (voir (Dugauquier, Engels, and Grosjean 2019) ). Cette discrimination est complexe sur base des vignettes.
La Figure 4.17 présente plusieurs vignettes de Sagittoidea.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Sagittoidae")




Figure 4.17: Vignettes de Chaetognatha




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe chaetognatha dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.18 ).


















Figure 4.18: Images de Chaetognatha du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).




4.2.2 Chaetognatha_head






Nouveau groupe



Dans les précédentes études (et set d’apprentissages associées), ce groupe n’a pas été discriminé.


Lors de l’échantillonnage, ces organismes peuvent être divisé en fragments. La tête est séparée du tronc et la queue ( Figure 4.19 ). Ce groupe reprend les têtes des organismes nommé head dans le ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).


















Figure 4.19: Images de tête de Chaetognatha du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).




4.2.3 Chaetognatha_tail






Nouveau groupe



Dans les précédentes études (et set d’apprentissages associées), ce groupe n’a pas été discriminé.


Lors de l’échantillonnage, ces organismes peuvent être divisé en fragments. La tête est séparée du tronc et la queue ( Figure 4.20 ). Ce groupe reprend les queues des organismes nommé tail__chaetognatha dans le ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)


















Figure 4.20: Images de queues de Chaetognatha du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)

title: 4  Plankton_gelatinous
text:
4.3 Ctenophora






Nouveau groupe



Dans les précédentes études (et set d’apprentissages associées), ce groupe n’a pas été discriminé.


La particularité anatomique de ce groupe est la présence de 8 peignes (bande composé de cils) qui permettent la locomotion de l’organisme. Ces bandes longitudinales sont symétriques tout autour de l’organisme.
Ce groupe est un groupe rare avec un nombre d’image très limitée 39 dans le ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).

title: 4  Plankton_gelatinous
text:
4.4 Cnidaria

4.4.1 Scyphozoa
Les schyphozoaires sont communément appelé méduses. Ces organismes sont à la fois benthiques et pélagiques (Licandro, Fischer, and Lindsay 2017). Les stades successifs du développement des méduse sont présentés ci-dessous.



Cycle de vie de Catostylus mosaicus (Scyphozoa: Rhizostomeae) (Pitt 2000).



4.4.1.1 Scyphozoa_ephyra
Le stade ephyra est aisément reconnaissable de par sa symétrie de 8 ( Figure 4.21 ). Les canaux radiaux et adriaticaux sont plus foncés sur les vignettes. La morphologie des canaux radiaux et adriaticaux peut être employée afin d’affiner la classification. Nous n’irons cependant pas plus loin dans cet ouvrage.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Scyphozoa_ephyra")




Figure 4.21: Vignettes du stade ephyra des Scyphozoa




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe ephyra dans le ZooScanNet (Figure 4.22).










Figure 4.22: Image du stade ephyra du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).




4.4.1.2 Scyphozoa_medusa
Au stade méduse, la symétrie de 8 est moins marqué. Les différents canaux sont toujours plus On observe. Les organismes sont généralement plus grand que ceux du stade ephyra ( Figure 4.23 ).



Figure 4.23: Vignette du stade meduse des scyphozoa


La Figure 4.23 présente plusieurs vignettes du stade méduse.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Scyphozoa_medusa", nx =2, ny = 2)




Figure 4.24: Vignettes du stade méduse des Scyphozoa




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe scyphozoa dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.25 ).


















Figure 4.25: Image du stade meduse du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)





4.4.2 Hydrozoa

4.4.2.1 Leptothecata

4.4.2.1.1 Campanulariidae

4.4.2.1.1.1 Obelia






Nouveau groupe



Dans les précédentes études (et set d’apprentissages associées), ce groupe n’a pas été discriminé.


Au centre, on retrouve la bouche de l’organisme relie par les canaux radiaires aux gonades. Le canal circulaire et les bulbes tentaculaires sont marqués à la base des tentacules ( Figure 4.26 ) .



Figure 4.26: Image de Leptomeduse Obelia sp (Hecq et al. 2009)


Ce groupe doit être similaire au groupe obelia dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.27 ).


















Figure 4.27: Image d’Obelia du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).






4.4.2.2 Siphonophorae
Les siphonophores sont une colonie d’individus que l’on nomme zoïdes. On discrimine différent zoïdes par rapport à leur fonctions nectophore (locomotion), gastrozoïde ( digestion), pneumatophore (flottaison) (Licandro, Carré, and Lindsay 2017).

4.4.2.2.1 Abilidae
Les abylidae ne possèdent pas de nectophores tout comme les Diphydae.

4.4.2.2.1.1 Abylopsis_tetragona_eudoxie
La Figure 4.28 présente sur la partie supérieur ce que nous classons dans la catégorie Abylopsis_tetragona_eudoxie et la partie inférieur Abylopsis_tetragona_gonophore .



Figure 4.28: Eudoxie d’ Abylopsis tetragona ( (Hecq et al. 2009))


La Figure 4.29 présente plusieurs vignettes du stade eudoxie d’Abylopsis tetragona (partie bractée). La forme pentagonale est très marquée ainsi que les gastrozoides plus denses sur les vignettes.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Abylopsis_tetragona_eudoxie")




Figure 4.29: Vignettes du stade eudoxie d’ Abylopsis tetragona.




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe eudoxie__Abylopsis_tetragona dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.30 ). Les deux premières images comprennent uniquement la partie bractée de l’organisme alors que les deux suivantes proposent la partie bractée et le gonophore.


















Figure 4.30: Image d’eudoxie d’ Abylopsis tetragona du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).




4.4.2.2.1.2 Abylopsis_tetragona_gonophore
La partie inférieur de la Figure 4.28 présente les gonophores d’une forme de prisme rectangulaire. La Figure 4.31 présente plusieurs vignettes du gonophore d’abylopsis tetragona.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Abylopsis_tetragona_gonophore", nx = 3, ny = 2)




Figure 4.31: Vignettes de gonophore d’ Abylopsis tetragona.




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe gonophore__Abylopsis_tetragona dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.35 ).










Figure 4.32: Image du gonophore d’ Abylopsis tetragona du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).




4.4.2.2.1.3 Abylopsis_tetragona_nectophore
Plusieurs éléments sont identifiables sur le nectophore antérieur des Abylidée (Figure 4.33) :

la forme pentagonales
la cavité sous ombrellaire (plus grande des 3 cavités, claire sur les vignettes)
gastrozoide (cavité la plus dense sur l’image)
somatocyste (cavité ovale avec un petit diverticule)




Figure 4.33: Nectophore antérieur d’ Abylidae (Hecq et al. 2009)


La Figure 4.34 présente plusieurs vignettes du nectophore d’abylopsis tetragona.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Abylopsis_tetragona_nectophore")




Figure 4.34: Vignettes de nectophore d’ Abylopsis tetragona.




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe nectophore__Abylopsis_tetragona dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.35 ).










Figure 4.35: Image de nectophore antérieur d’ Abylopsis tetragona du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018).


La Figure 4.36 propose une organisme complet doté de son nectophore antérieur et de son nectophore postérieur



Figure 4.36: Image du nectophore antérieur et postérieur d’ Abylopsis tetragona du ZooScanNet ((Elineau et al. 2018)).





4.4.2.2.2 Diphydae

4.4.2.2.2.1 Diphyidae_gonophore
La série de vignettes présente les gonophore qui sont la partie reproductrice du stade eudoxie. On retrouve une certaine ressemblance avec les gonophores d’Abylopsis tetragona sans le prisme rectangulaire ( Figure 4.37 ).

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Diphyidae_gonophore")




Figure 4.37: Vignettes de gonophore de Diphyidae.




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe gonophore__Diphyidae dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.38 ).




Figure 4.38: Image de gonophores de Diphyidae du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)




4.4.2.2.2.2 Diphyidae_nectophore
Les nectophores des Diphyidae sont de formes coniques. Le nectosac est plus densus sur les vignettes ci-dessous. Le long du nectosac, on observe les somatocystes ( Figure 4.39 ).

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Diphyidae_nectophore")




Figure 4.39: Vignettes de nectophores de Diphyidae.










Note



Le ZooScanNet propose deux groupes : eudoxie__diphyidae et nectophore__diphyidae . Nous faisons le choix de les regrouper en un seul et unique groupe : Diphyidae_nectophore .





4.4.2.2.3 Physonectae

4.4.2.2.3.1 Physonectae_nectophore
Ces organismes sont constitués d’un pneumatophore contrairement aux Calycophore. La forme particulière de ces organismes les rendent aisément identifiables. On observe un resserrement à la base de la colonie.



A: Photographie [@pugh2016] et B: vignette de Physonectae.


La Figure 4.40 présente plusieurs vignettes du stade méduse.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Physonectae_nectophore")




Figure 4.40: Vignettes de nectophore de Physonectae.




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe nectophore_Physonectae dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.41 ).










Figure 4.41: Image de physonectae du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)






4.4.2.3 Trachymedusea

4.4.2.3.1 Rhopalonematidae

4.4.2.3.1.1 Aglaura
La Figure 4.42 présente plusieurs vignettes de Rhopalonematidae. La forme assez particulière de ce genre permet de l’identifier assez aisément. La partie plus dense dans la partie supérieur de l’organisme est son estomac et les ses gonages suspendue par un pédoncule.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Aglaura")




Figure 4.42: Vignettes d’Aglaura.




Ce groupe est similaire au groupe Aglaura dans le ZooScanNet ( Figure 4.43 ).










Figure 4.43: Image d’Aglaura du ZooScanNet (Elineau et al. 2018)







Caicci, Federico, Fabio Gasparini, Francesca Rigon, Giovanna Zaniolo, Paolo Burighel, and Lucia Manni. 2013. “The Oral Sensory Structures of Thaliacea (Tunicata) and Consideration of the Evolution of Hair Cells in Chordata: Oral Sensory Structures in Thaliacea.” Journal of Comparative Neurology 521 (12): 2756–71. https://doi.org/10.1002/cne.23313.


Dugauquier, Rémy. 2019. “Classification Supervisée Du Mésozooplancton de Calvi : Mise Au Point de Méthodes d’étude Des Classes Rares d’un Set d’apprentissage Et Mise En Contexte Environnemental.” PhD thesis, Mons, Belgique.


Dugauquier, Rémy, Guyliann Engels, and Philippe Grosjean. 2019. Guide d’identification des organismes mésozooplanctoniques de la Mer Ligurienne. https://econum.github.io/zooimage_mesozooplankton_guide2/.


Elineau, Amanda, Corinne Desnos, Laetitia Jalabert, Marion Olivier, Jean-Baptiste Romagnan, Manoela Costa Brandao, Fabien Lombard, et al. 2018. “ZooScanNet: Plankton Images Captured with the ZooScan.” https://doi.org/10.17882/55741.


Gorsky, Gaby, and Claudia Castellani. 2017. “Chordata: Appendicularia.” In. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/oso/9780199233267.003.0040.


Hecq, Jean-Henri, Amandine Collignon, and Anne Goffart. 2014. “Atlas du zooplancton des eaux côtières corses, version du 04/06/2014. Travail de synthèse réalisé à la demande de l’agende de l’eau RMC.” https://orbi.uliege.be/handle/2268/168629.


Hecq, Jean-Henri, Anne Goffart, Amandine Collignon, Sylvain Plazza, Pierre Simon DEFREYGNE, and Pierre Lejeune. 2009. “La Variabilité de La Méduse Pelagia Noctiluca (Forskål, 1775) En Baie de Calvi (Corse) En Relation Avec l’environnement.” Calvi, Corse.


Licandro, Priscillia, Claude Carré, and Dhugal J. Lindsay. 2017. “Cnidaria: Colonial Hydrozoa (Siphonophorae).” In. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/oso/9780199233267.001.0001.


Licandro, Priscillia, Astrid Fischer, and Dhugal J. Lindsay. 2017. “Cnidaria: Scyphozoa and Non-Colonial Hydrozoa.” In. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/oso/9780199233267.001.0001.


Pierrot-Bults, A. C. 2020. “Chaetognatha : ICES IDENTIFICATION LEAFLETS FOR PLANKTON,” no. 193 (November). https://doi.org/10.17895/ICES.PUB.7564.


Pierrots-Bults, Annelies. 2017. “Chaetognatha.” In. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/oso/9780199233267.003.0033.


Pitt, K. A. 2000. “Life History and Settlement Preferences of the Edible Jellyfish Catostylus Mosaicus (Scyphozoa: Rhizostomeae).” Marine Biology 136 (2): 269–79. https://doi.org/10.1007/s002270050685.


Quivy, Thomas. 2018. “Le Mésozooplancton de La Baie de Calvi, Corse : 2tude Comparatve Entre Traits Verticaux Et Horizontaux.” PhD thesis, Mons, Belgique.


Ruppert, Edward E., Richard S. Fox, and Robert D. Barnes. 2004. Invertebrate Zoology: A Functional Evolutionary Approach. 7th ed. Belmont, CA: Thomson-Brooks/Cole.

title: 5  Plankton_small
text:
source("R/init.R")
vigns <- fs::dir_ls(
  here::here(training_dir, "Plankton_small"), 
  type = "file", glob = "*.png", recurse = TRUE)

title: 5  Plankton_small
text:
5.1 Egg_Small_larva

5.1.1 Small_larva

5.1.1.1 Echinoidea_pluteus






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


The Echinoidea is a class of Echinoderms. The main characteristics of Echinoderms are have a pentamerous radial symmetry, an internal skelleton and a mutable connective tissue. Sea stars, sea cucumbers and sea urchins can be found in this phylum. The Sea urchins are the main organisms of the class Echinoidae. The Echinoplueus is the free swimming larva of Echinoidae. This larva is small in size and has six pairs of long larval arms. It looks like an ophiopluteus. However, ophiopluteus have two longer larval arms than the others (Section 5.1.1.2). The Echinoidae has regular and irregular externals structures. The larva of regular species have all their arms in the same direction (Figure 5.1)


















Figure 5.1: Image of regular echinopluteus (Elineau et al. 2018)


The larva of irregular species is a long larval arm opposite the other arms (Figure 5.2).


















Figure 5.2: Image of irregular echinopluteus (Elineau et al. 2018)




5.1.1.2 Ophiuroidea_pluteus






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


The Ophiuroidae is a class of Echinoderms. The ophioplueus is the free swimming larva of Ophiuroidae. This larva is also small in size and looks like an echinopluteus. It t has 8 long larval arms, 2 of which are very long (Figure 5.3).


















Figure 5.3: Images of ophiopluteus (Elineau et al. 2018).




5.1.1.3 Crustacea_small_larva

5.1.1.3.1 Crustacea_metanauplius






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


The metanauplius have a long body with six appendages ( antennules, antennae, and mandibles). On the vignettes, the six appendages are not always visible (Figure 5.5).

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Crustacea_metanauplius", nx = 2, ny = 2)




Figure 5.4: Vignettes of the metanauplius




This group is similar to the metanauplii group in ZooScanNet ( Figure 5.5 ).


















Figure 5.5: Images of metanauplius (Elineau et al. 2018)




5.1.1.3.2 Crustacea_nauplius
The Nauplius of the crustacea have Egg-shaped body with six appendages ( antennules, antennae, and mandibles) ( Figure 5.6 ).

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Crustacea_nauplius", nx = 5, ny = 5)




Figure 5.6: Vignettes of the nauplius




This group is similar to the nauplii__Crustaceae group in ZooScanNet ( Figure 5.7 ).
























Figure 5.7: Images of nauplii (Elineau et al. 2018).




5.1.1.3.3 Cirripedia_nauplius






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.








In progress



This section is not yet completed




5.1.1.3.4 Cirripedia_cypris






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


This group is similar to the nauplii__Crustaceae group in ZooScanNet ( Figure 5.8 ). This larvae have an elongated caparace with a nauplii eye darker on the ZooScanNet images. The appendages are not always visible.


















Figure 5.8: Images of the cypris stage of Cirripedia (Elineau et al. 2018)





5.1.1.4 Bryozoa_cyphonautes






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


Bryozoa is a phylum of aquatic organisms. The main characteristics of bryozoa is the lophophore. The lophophore is ring of tentacles around the mouth.
The cyphonautes have a triangular shape. At the base of the triangle is a coronna. It is a ciliated band (Figure 5.9).


















Figure 5.9: Images of cyphonautes (Elineau et al. 2018)





5.1.2 Egg

5.1.2.1 Mollusca_egg






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


In the ZooSCanNet, there are a specific group for egg of Cavolina inflexa. They are often found in groups.These eggs are cone-shaped (Figure 5.10). They have a similar shape to the adults (Section 3.1.2.1.2).


















Figure 5.10: Images of the eggs of Cavolina inflexa (Elineau et al. 2018)




5.1.2.2 Actinopterygii_egg
The identification of fish eggs is complicated. Different criteria are used such as the structure of the yolk, the presence (or not) of peri-vitelin space or the diameter of the egg. There are exceptions like anchovy eggs which are oblong and not spherical.
Crec’hriou, Marinaro, and Planes (2015) have proposed an identification guide of pelagic eggs of mediterranean fish. This guide uses eggs at stage 5.

5.1.2.2.1 Actinopterygii_egg_stage1






In progress



This section is not yet completed




5.1.2.2.2 Actinopterygii_egg_stage2






In progress



This section is not yet completed




5.1.2.2.3 Actinopterygii_egg_stage3






In progress



This section is not yet completed




5.1.2.2.4 Actinopterygii_egg_stage4






In progress



This section is not yet completed




5.1.2.2.5 Actinopterygii_egg_stage5
At this stage, the embryo is clearly visible and surrounds the yolk sac. The oil globule is usually visible (Figure 5.11).



Figure 5.11: Schema of fish eggs at stage 5 (Rodriguez, Alemany, and Garcia 2017).


Figure 5.12 shows several vignettes of actinopterygii eggs at stage 5.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Actinopterygii_egg_stage5")




Figure 5.12: Vignettes of actinopterygii eggs at stage 5




In the ZooScanNet, egg__actinopterygii group consists mainly of eggs at stage 5 (Figure 5.13).


















Figure 5.13: Images of actinopterygii eggs at stage 5 (Elineau et al. 2018)





5.1.2.3 Egg_other
This group includes vignettes that are not fish eggs and mollusc eggs. The Figure 5.14 shows several eggs containing nauplii.

plot_vignettes(vigns, group = "Egg_other")




Figure 5.14: Vignettes of the eggs of nauplia




This group is similar to the egg__other group in ZooScanNet (?fig-zsn-sgg-other).


















Figure 5.15: Image of various eggs (Elineau et al. 2018)

title: 5  Plankton_small
text:
5.2 Chromista

5.2.1 Bacillariophyceae

5.2.1.1 Coscinodiscales

5.2.1.1.1 Coscinodiscus






New group



In previous studies (and associated training sets), this group was not studied.


Coscinodiscus is a diatom. The main characteristics of diatom is frustule (cell wall made of silica). The Coscinodiscus have a cylindrical shape. The
The base of the cylinder is spherical with a darker periphery ( Figure 5.16 ) while the edge is square with light and dark bands ( Figure 5.17 ).


















Figure 5.16: Images of the base of the Coscinodiscus




















Figure 5.17: Images of the edge of Coscinodiscus







Crec’hriou, Romain, Jean-Yves Marinaro, and Serge Planes. 2015. “Advance in Identification of Pelagic Eggs of Mediterranean Fish: Development of a New Identification Key.” Vie Et Milieu 65 (January): 47–61.


Elineau, Amanda, Corinne Desnos, Laetitia Jalabert, Marion Olivier, Jean-Baptiste Romagnan, Manoela Costa Brandao, Fabien Lombard, et al. 2018. “ZooScanNet: Plankton Images Captured with the ZooScan.” https://doi.org/10.17882/55741.


Rodriguez, J. M., F. Alemany, and A. Garcia. 2017. A Guide to the Eggs and Larvae of 100 Common Western Mediterranean Sea Body Fish Species. Rome, Italy: FOOD AND AGRICULTURE ORGANIZATION OF THE UNITED NATIONS. https://www.fao.org/documents/card/fr/c/35f5bb5c-bee9-46c3-a6d5-e92b00fe05c7/.
